Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Huanan Zhang of University of Michigan to conduct a research project, entitled "Gold Nanorods for fast detection of prions in complex biological fluids," during the summer of 2012 at Jiangnan University in Wuxi, Jiangshu Province, China. The host scientist is Professor Chuanlai Xu.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to develop a new approach for misfolded protein detection that takes advantage of unique properties of nanoparticle assemblies, and existing knowledge of protein detection on nanoparticle assembly.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanomaterials have been investigated extensively in research development in the past. Many improved new products have been developed by utilizing nanomaterials and would benefit the general public and humanity if we apply them correctly. Nevertheless, there has been public concern regards to the health safety of nanomaterials. In general, our knowledge of nanomaterial toxicity effect is limited. This study allows us to have a better understanding of nanomaterials toxicity. Cellular toxicity is a very complex process and depends on the type, shape, and size of material. Increasingly, more and more research has been focus on nanomaterial assembly. Nanomaterial assembly takes advantage of the collective properties of different nanomaterial types to create even more exciting material properties. It is well established that the correlation of cellular toxicity and the concentration of the nanoparticles. Cellular toxicity induced by nanostructures is much less understood. The question remains: Would assembled nanostructures induce the same type of toxicity as normal nanomaterials?  Our study contributes significantly understanding of cellular toxicity induced by nanostructures. In our study, we systemically studied the toxicity of different types of nanomaterials (dimer and satellite structures) in cell culture experiments with neural cell.  Our study showed that different assembled nanostructures induced different level of cellular toxicity.  

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2012
Modified by: Huanan Zhang
